en: Radar is the last to get off the phone, and when he finally does, he says, “I’d like to make an announcement. My parents are very annoyed that I’m missing graduation. My girlfriend is also annoyed, because we were scheduled to do something very special in about eight hours. I don’t want to get into details about it, but this had better be one fun road trip.”
vi: Radar là đứa cuối cùng đặt điện thoại xuống, rút cục nó thông báo, “Tôi xin tuyên bố đây. Bố mẹ tôi rất cáu vì tôi không dự lễ tốt nghiệp. Bạn gái tôi cũng cáu, vì hai đứa đã lên kế hoạch làm một việc đặc biệt trong vòng tám tiếng nữa. Tôi không muốn đi vào tiểu tiết, nhưng tốt hơn hết đây nên là một chuyến bám đường hoành tráng.
vi_results: "title": "Đời Sống Mới Lại Lịch Sử", "author": "Nguyễn Nhật Ánh"
tr: Radar telefondan kurtulan son kişi ve nihayet kurtulduğunda şöyle diyor: “Bir duyuru yapmak istiyorum. Ebeveynlerim mezuniyeti kaçırmama sinirlendiler. Kız arkadaşım da sinirlendi çünkü yaklaşık sekiz saat içinde çok özel bir şey yapmayı planlıyorduk. Ayrıntıya girmek istemiyorum ama gerçekten eğlenceli bir yolculuk olsa iyi olur.
tr_results: "title": "The Perks of Being a Wallflower", "author": "Stephen Chbosky"
es: Radar es el último en colgar el teléfono, y cuando por fin lo hace, dice: —Me gustaría comunicaros algo: mis padres están muy enfadados porque no esté en la graduación. Mi novia también está muy enfadada, porque habíamos organizado algo muy especial dentro de ocho horas. No quiero entrar en detalles, pero más vale que el viaje sea divertido.
vi_translation: Radar was the last one to put down the phone, finally announcing, "I declare this. My parents are very angry because I'm not attending the graduation ceremony. My girlfriend is also angry because we had planned to do something special in the next eight hours. I don't want to go into details, but this better be an epic road trip."
tr_translation: The last person to escape from the radar phone, and when he finally escaped, he said: "I want to make an announcement. My parents were angry that I missed the graduation. My girlfriend was also angry because we were planning to do something very special in about eight hours. I don't want to go into details, but it better be a really fun trip."
es_translation: Radar is the last one to hang up the phone, and when he finally does, he says: —I would like to tell you something: my parents are very angry because I am not at the graduation. My girlfriend is also very angry, because we had organized something very special in eight hours. I don't want to go into details, but the trip better be fun.
st: Radar ke oa ho qetela ho theoha mohala, 'me ha a qetella a etsa joalo, o re, "Nka rata ho etsa tsebiso. Batsoali ba ka ba tšoenyehile haholo ka hore ha ke na diploma. Motsoalle oa ka o boetse o tšoenyehile, hobane re ne re reretsoe ho etsa ntho e khethehileng haholo hoo e ka bang lihora tse ka bang robeli. Ha ke batle ho fumana lintlha ka eona, empa sena se ne se le betere ho feta leeto la tsela. "
yo: Radar ni ẹni tí ó gbẹ̀yìn láti kúrò lórí ẹ̀rọ ìbánisọ̀rọ̀, àti pé nígbà tí ó bá ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀ nígbẹ̀yìn, ó sọ pé, "Mà á fẹ́ láti ṣe ìkéde. Inú ń bí àwọn òbí mi gan-an pé mi ò lè pàdánù ayẹyẹ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ jáde. Inú bí ọ̀rẹ́bìnrin mi, nítorí wọ́n ṣètò láti ṣe nkan pàtàkì láàárín bíi wákàtí mẹ́jọ. Mi ò fẹ́ ṣe àlàyé nípa rẹ̀, ṣùgbọ́n èyí dára kí ó jẹ́ ìrìn-àjò ọ̀nà ìgbádùn kan."
tn: O ne a bua jaana ka mogala mme fa kgabagare a re: "Ke batla go dira sengwe se se molemo. Batsadi ba me ba ne ba galefa thata fa ke sa ntse ke le mo sekolong. Le fa go ntse jalo, mmamalome o tshwenngwa ke go dira sengwe se se kgethegileng thata mo sebakeng sa diura di le robedi. Ga ke rate go bua ka dilo tse, mme gone go ne go le botoka go nna le leeto le le itumedisang."
ty: O Radar te taata hopea tei matara mai na roto i te niuniu paraparau, e ia na reira ana'e oia, ua parau mai oia, " Te hinaaro nei au e faaite i te hoê parau faaara. Ua inoino roa to ' u mau metua i te mea e aita vau e faatuitehia ra. Ua inoino atoa to ' u hoa vahine, no te mea ua faanahohia e rave i te tahi ohipa taa ê roa i roto e vau hora. Aita vau e hinaaro ia ite i te mau mea no ni'a i te reira, tera râ, e mea maitai a'e ia haere na ni'a i te purumu ".
mai: रडार फोनसँ उतरयवला अन्तिम व्यक्ति छथि, आ जखन ओ अन्ततः करैत छथि तखन ओ कहैत छथि, "हम एकटा घोषणा करय चाहब। हमर माता-पिता बहुत नाराज छथि जे हम स्नातक नहि कए रहल छी। हमर प्रेमिका सेहो नाराज छथि, किएक तँ हमरासभकेँ लगभग आठ घंटाक भीतर किछु बहुत खास करबाक छल। हम एहि विषयमे विस्तार सँ नहि जानय चाहैत छी, मुदा ई एकटा मजेदार सड़क यात्रा हेबाक चाही।"
mg: Radar no farany niala tamin'ny telefaonina, ary rehefa manao izany izy amin'ny farany, dia hoy izy: "Te-hanao fanambarana aho. Tezitra be ny ray aman-dreniko satria tsy nahazo diplaoma aho. Sorena koa ilay sipako, satria efa nomanina hanao zavatra tena miavaka izahay tao anatin'ny adiny valo teo ho eo. Tsy te-hiditra amin'ny antsipiriany momba izany aho, saingy tsara kokoa ny mandeha amin'ny làlana mahafinaritra."

en: By now we are on I-4, and traffic is fairly light, which in and of itself is borderline miraculous. I’m in the far left lane driving eight miles an hour over the fifty-five-miles-per-hour speed limit, because I heard once that you don’t get pulled over until you’re going nine miles an hour over the speed limit.
vi: Chúng tôi đang đi trên cao tốc liên bang I-4, giao thông tương đối thưa, chính thế càng thêm phần may mắn không ngờ. Tôi đang chạy xe ở làn ngoài cùng bên trái, vượt tám dặm một giờ so với tốc độ cho phép năm mươi lăm dặm một giờ, vì có lần tôi từng nghe nói rằng phải vượt đến chín dặm một giờ mới bị cảnh sát bắt dừng lại.
tr: Artık I4’teyiz ve trafik oldukça az ki bu gerçekten bir mucize. Saatte doksan kilometrelik hız sınırından on dört kilometre fazla hızla, en sol şeritte gidiyorum çünkü bir keresinde hız sınırından on beş kilometre hızh sürünce arabanın polis tarafından kenara çekilmediğini duydum.
es: Estamos en la I-4, y el tráfico es fluido, lo que en sí mismo roza lo milagroso. Vamos por el carril de la izquierda a diez kilómetros por hora por encima del límite de velocidad, que es de noventa, porque una vez me dijeron que solo te pillan si te pasas más de quince kilómetros.
vi_translation: We are driving on the I-4 interstate, the traffic is relatively sparse, which makes it even more unexpectedly fortunate. I am driving in the far left lane, exceeding the speed limit of fifty-five miles per hour by eight miles per hour, because I once heard that you have to exceed by nine miles per hour to be stopped by the police.
tr_translation: We are now on I4 and the traffic is quite light, which is truly a miracle. I am driving in the far left lane at fourteen kilometers per hour over the ninety kilometers per hour speed limit because I once heard that the police don't pull over cars that are only fifteen kilometers per hour over the speed limit.
es_translation: We are on the I-4, and the traffic is smooth, which in itself borders on the miraculous. We are in the left lane going ten kilometers per hour above the speed limit, which is ninety, because once I was told that they only catch you if you exceed by more than fifteen kilometers.
st: Hajoale re le ho I-4, 'me sephethephethe se bobebe ka mokhoa o hlakileng, oo ho oona le ka boeona e leng borderline mohlolo. Ke tseleng e hole le letšehali khanna lik'hilomithara tse robeli ka hora ho feta moeli oa lebelo la lik'hilomithara tse mashome a mahlano, hobane ke utloile hang ha o sa hula ho fihlela o ea lik'hilomithara tse robong ka hora ho feta moeli oa lebelo.
yo: Ní báyìí a ti wà lórí I-4, àti pé ọkọ̀ jẹ́ ìmọ́lẹ̀ díẹ̀, èyí tí ó jẹ́ ìyanu nínú àti fúnra rẹ̀ jẹ́ ìyanu ààlà. Mo wà ní ọ̀nà òsì tí mò ń wa ọkọ̀ máìlì mẹ́jọ ní wákàtí kan lórí òpin ìyára máìlì márùndínlọ́gọ́ta fún wákàtí kan, nítorí mo gbọ́ nígbà kan pé wọn kò dá ọ dúró títí tí o fi ń lọ máìlì mẹ́sàn-án ní wákàtí kan ju òpin ìyára lọ.
tn: 4 Jaanong re mo go I-4, mme tsela e e tlhamaletseng, e e mo teng le ka boyona e le kgakgamatso ya molelwane. en: “Oh, I know!” I say from the front. “You spy a twenty-four-hour road trip in a minivan. Hip because road trips always are; tragic because the gas we’re guzzling will destroy the planet.”
vi: “Ồ, tôi biết!” tôi nói vọng xuống. “Ông phát hiện ra hành trình bám đường dài hai mươi tư tiếng trong một chiếc minivan. Sành điệu vì những chuyến bám đường luôn như vậy; khủng khiếp vì lượng xăng bọn mình ngốn sẽ phá hủy hành tinh này.”

en: Radar says no, and they keep guessing. I am driving and going seventy-two and praying not to get a ticket and playing Metaphysical I Spy. The tragically hip thing turns out to be failing to turn in your rented graduation robes on time. I blow past a cop parked on the grass median. I grip the steering wheel hard with both hands, feeling sure he’ll race up to pull us over. But he doesn’t. Maybe he knows I’m only speeding because I have to.
en_results: "title": "Maybe You Should Talk to Someone", "author": "Lori Gottlieb"
vi: Radar vẫn bảo không phải, và chúng tôi lại đoán tiếp. Tôi đang lái xe, giữ tốc độ bảy mươi hai dặm một giờ, cầu mong không bị phạt vi phạm giao thông và đang chơi Tôi Phát Hiện phiên bản siêu hình. Điều sành điệu khủng khiếp hóa ra là việc mớ áo chùng đi thuê này sẽ không được đem trả đúng hẹn. Tôi nhấn ga chạy nhanh qua một cảnh sát đang dừng trên dải cỏ phân cách. Tôi nắm chặt vô-lăng bằng cả hai tay, cảm tưởng chắc như ăn bắp là chú cảnh sát sẽ đuổi theo và tấp tôi vào lề đường. Nhưng chú ấy không đuổi theo, chắc biết rằng tôi chỉ phóng nhanh vì tôi buộc phải như vậy.
tr: Radar hayır diyor ve tahmin yürütmeye devam ediyorlar. Arabayı sürüyorum, yüz on beşle gidiyorum ve trafik cezası almamak için dua ederken Fizikötesi Görüyorum oynuyorum. Trajik bir şekilde moda olan şeyin, kiralık mezuniyet cübbesini zamanında iade etmemek olduğu ortaya çıkıyor. Refüjde park etmiş bir polis arabasının yamndan rüzgâr gibi geçiyorum. Bizi kenara çekmek için hızla geleceğinden emin bir şekilde iki elimle direksiyona sıkıca yapışıyorum. Ama öyle yapmıyor. Belki de yalnızca mecbur olduğum için hız yaptığımı biliyor.
es: Radar dice que no y siguen intentando adivinarlo. Me mantengo en ciento quince kilómetros por hora, rezo para que no me pongan una multa y juego al veo veo metafísico. Lo trágicamente a la última resulta ser no conseguir devolver las togas alquiladas a tiempo. Dejo atrás a toda velocidad un coche de policía parado en la mediana de hierba. Sujeto el volante con fuerza, con las dos manos, convencido de que va a perseguirnos y a hacernos parar. Pero no. Quizá el poli sabe que voy a esa velocidad porque no me queda más remedio.
es_results: "title": "Matar a un ruiseñor en el camino", "author": "Javier Marías"
vi_translation: Radar still insisted it wasn't, and we continued guessing. I was driving, maintaining a speed of seventy-two miles per hour, hoping not to get a traffic ticket, and playing a metaphysical version of I Spy. The terribly stylish thing turned out to be that this rented robe wouldn't be returned on time. I pressed the gas pedal to speed past a police officer who was stopped on the median strip. I gripped the steering wheel with both hands, feeling certain that the officer would chase after me and pull me over. But he didn't chase after me, probably knowing that I was speeding because I had to.
tr_translation: Radar says no and they continue to guess. I'm driving the car, going at one hundred fifteen, and playing Metaphysical I Spy while praying not to get a speeding ticket. It turns out that the tragically fashionable thing is not returning the rented graduation gown on time. I speed past a police car parked on the median like the wind. Gripping the steering wheel tightly with both hands, I'm certain it will quickly come to pull us over. But it doesn't. Maybe it knows that I'm speeding only because I have to.
es_translation: Radar says no and they keep trying to guess it. I maintain a speed of one hundred and fifteen kilometers per hour, pray that I don't get a ticket, and play metaphysical I spy. The tragically up-to-date thing turns out to be not being able to return the rented robes on time. I speed past a police car stopped in the grassy median. I grip the steering wheel tightly with both hands, convinced that it will chase us and make us stop. But no. Maybe the cop knows that I'm going at this speed because I have no other choice.
st: Radar o re che, 'me ba lula ba nahana. Ke khanna le ho ea mashome a supileng a metso e 'meli' me ke rapela hore ke se ke ka fumana tekete le ho bapala Metaphysical I Spy. Ntho e bohloko ka ho fetesisa e kanna ea se ke ea fetoa ke liaparo tsa hau tsa mangolo ka nako. ʻO ka hoʻoholo ʻana i ka hoʻoholo ʻana i ka hoʻoholo ʻana. Ke ts'oana le matsoho a ka ka bobeli, ke ts'epa hore o tla re sututsa. Empa ha a etse joalo. Kea tseba hore o potlakile haholo hobane ke tla tlameha ho e etsa.

Nkan ìbàdí ìbànújẹ́ náà kùnà láti yí aṣọ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́yege rẹ tí wọ́n yá padà ní àsìkò. Mo fẹ́ kọjá ọlọ́pàá kan tí ó dúró sí àárín koríko. Mo mú kẹ̀kẹ́ ìdarí náà gidigidi pẹ̀lú ọwọ́ méjèèjì, mo ní ìdánilójú pé yóò sáré sókè láti fà wá dúró. Ṣùgbọ́n kò ṣe é. Bóyá ó mọ̀ pé mo kàn ń sáré nítorí pé mo ní láti ṣe é ni.

ty: Te parau ra o Radar e aita, e te tamau noa ra ratou i te uiui haere. Te faahoro ra vau i te pereoo e te haere ra vau e hitu ahuru ma piti matahiti e te pure nei au eiaha e rave i te hoê titeti e ia ha'uti i te metaphysical I Spy. Te mea peapea roa ' ' e, o te oreraa ïa e faaho'i i to outou ahu faatuiteraa i te hora tia. Ua pupuhi au na piha'i iho i te hoê ro'i i ni'a i te matie. en: “Q. Sweetie. You’re a boy. You don’t know how to do these things. The NoDoz is with the chocolate and the Mountain Dew, because those things all contain caffeine and help you stay up. The NyQuil is with the beef jerky because eating meat makes you feel tired.”
en_results: "title": "The Perks of Being a Wallflower", "author": "Stephen Chbosky"
vi: “Q thân mến, chàng trai ngây thơ quá, làm sao hiểu được phạm trù này. NoDoz đi với sô-cô-la và Mountain Dew, vì những thứ đó đều có ca-phê-in và làm cậu tỉnh. NyQuil ở cùng thịt bò khô vì ăn thịt sẽ làm cậu mệt.”
tr: “Q. Tatlım. Sen bir erkeksin. Böyle şeylerin nasıl yapılacağını bilmezsin. NoDoz, çikolata ve Mountain Dew’la birlikte çünkü bunların hepsi kafein içeriyor ve uyanık kalmana yardımcı oluyorlar. NyQuil kurutulmuş etle birlikte çünkü et yemek yorgun hissetmene neden olur.
es: —Q, cariño, eres un crío. No sabes cómo van estas cosas. La cafeína va con el chocolate y el Mountain Dew, que también tienen cafeína, que sirve para mantenerte despierto. El antihistamínico, que da sueño, va con la cecina porque comer carne hace que te canses.
vi_translation: “Dear Q, you are too naive to understand this category. NoDoz goes with chocolate and Mountain Dew because they all contain caffeine and keep you awake. NyQuil goes with beef jerky because eating meat will make you tired.”
tr_translation: “Q. Sweetheart. You are a man. You don't know how to do these things. NoDoz, chocolate, and Mountain Dew together because they all contain caffeine and help you stay awake. NyQuil with jerky because eating meat makes you feel tired.”
es_translation: —Q, darling, you are a kid. You don't know how these things work. Caffeine goes with chocolate and Mountain Dew, which also have caffeine, which helps to keep you awake. The antihistamine, which makes you sleepy, goes with jerky because eating meat makes you tired.

en: We’re driving alongside a Hispanic woman in a beat-up old Toyota Corolla. I watch her through the early darkness. “Left her family to move here,” I say. “Illegal. Sends money back home on the third Tuesday of every month. She’s got two little kids—her husband is a migrant. He’s in Ohio right now—he only spends three or four months a year at home, but they still get along really well.”
vi: Chúng tôi lái song song một cô người Hispanic[9] đi chiếc Toyota Corolla đã cũ. Tôi quan sát cô ấy khi trời bắt đầu nhập nhoạng. “Bỏ gia đình để đến đây,” tôi nói. “Cư trú bất hợp pháp. Gửi tiền về nhà vào thứ Ba của tuần thứ ba hàng tháng. Cô ấy có hai con nhỏ–chồng là dân di cư. Hiện giờ chú chồng đang ở Ohio–một năm chỉ ở nhà khoảng ba, bốn tháng, nhưng hai vợ chồng vẫn rất ổn.
vi_results: "title": "The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao", "author": "Junot Diaz"
tr: Oldukça eski bir Toyota Corolla’daki Hispanik bir kadınla yan yana gidiyoruz. Erken çöken karanlığın içinden kadım izliyorum. “Buraya taşınmak için ailesini terk etmiş,” diyorum. “Yasadışı. Her ayın üçüncü sah gününde eve para gönderiyor. İki küçük çocuğu var, kocası göçmen. Şu anda Ohio’da, yılda sadece üç dört ayı evde geçiriyor ama yine de gerçekten iyi geçiniyorlar.
tr_results: "title": "The Brief Wondrous Life of Oscar Wao", "author": "Junot Diaz"
es: Vamos al lado de una mujer hispana que conduce un viejo y destartalado Toyota Corolla. La observo en la temprana oscuridad. —Dejó a su familia para venirse aquí —digo—. Sin papeles. Manda dinero a su casa el tercer martes de cada mes. Tiene dos hijos pequeños. Su marido es inmigrante. En estos momentos vive en Ohio. Solo pasa tres o cuatro meses al año en su casa, pero su familia se las arregla bastante bien.
vi_translation: We drove alongside a Hispanic woman[9] in an old Toyota Corolla. I watched her as the sky began to darken. “Left her family to come here,” I said. “Living here illegally. Sends money home on the third Tuesday of every month. She has two small children–her husband is a migrant worker. Right now, her husband is in Ohio–he's only home about three or four months a year, but the couple is doing just fine.”
tr_translation: We are driving side by side with a Hispanic woman in a rather old Toyota Corolla. I am watching the woman through the early falling darkness. "She left her family to move here," I say. "Illegal. She sends money home on the third day of every month. Two small children Her husband is an immigrant. Currently, he is in Ohio, spending only three or four months a year at home, but they still get along really well.”
es_translation: We go next to a Hispanic woman driving an old and dilapidated Toyota Corolla. I observe her in the early darkness. —She left her family to come here —I say—. Without papers. She sends money home on the third Tuesday of every month. She has two small children. Her husband is an immigrant. At the moment, she lives in Ohio. She only spends three or four months a year at home, but her family manages quite well.
st: Re khanna le mosali oa Sepanishe ho Toyota Corolla ea khale. Ke tla mo bona a le lefifing la pele. Ke ile ka re, "Ke kopa hore lelapa la hao le falle mona." "Ho seng molaong. en: The minivan has become a kind of very small house: I am sitting in the passenger seat, which is the den. This is, I think, the best room in the house: there is plenty of space, and the chair is quite comfortable.
en_results: "title": "A Small Place in the Country", "author": "Peter Mayle"
vi: Chiếc minivan đã trở thành một mái nhà nho nhỏ: Tôi đang ngồi ở ghế cạnh lái xe, chỗ này là phòng thư giãn. Tôi nghĩ đây là phòng tốt nhất trong nhà: rất rộng rãi, ghế khá thoải mái.
tr: Minivan bir bakıma küçük bir eve dönüştü: Ben dinlenme odası olan ön koltukta oturuyorum. Bu bence evin en iyi odası çünkü geniş ve koltuk oldukça rahat.
tr_results: "title": "The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy", "author": "Douglas Adams"
es: El monovolumen se ha convertido en una especie de casa diminuta. Yo estoy sentado en el asiento del copiloto, que es la sala de estar. Creo que es la mejor habitación de la casa. Es amplia y el asiento es muy cómodo.
vi_translation: The minivan has become a small home: I am sitting in the passenger seat, this is the relaxation room. I think this is the best room in the house: very spacious, the seat is quite comfortable.
tr_translation: The minivan has in a way turned into a small house: I am sitting in the front seat, which serves as a lounge. I think this is the best room in the house because it is spacious and the seat is quite comfortable.
es_translation: The minivan has turned into a kind of tiny house. I am sitting in the passenger seat, which is the living room. I think it is the best room in the house. It is spacious and the seat is very comfortable.
st: Minivan e fetohile mofuta oa ntlo e nyane haholo: Ke lutse setulong sa baeti, e leng lehaha. Sena ke, ke nahana hore, kamore e ntle ka ho fetisisa ka tlung: ho na le sebaka se ngata, 'me setulo se phutholohile haholo.
yo: Minivan náà ti di irú ilé kékeré kan: mo jókòó sí ìjókòó àwọn èrò, èyí tí ó jẹ́ ihò náà. Èyí ni, mo rò pé, yàrá tó dára jùlọ nínú ilé: ààyè púpọ̀ wà, àga náà sì rọrùn.
tn: Minivan e ne ya nna mofuta wa ntlo e nnye thata: Ke nna mo setulong sa bapalami, e leng logaga lwa lewatle. Ke nagana gore phaposi e e gaisang mo ntlong: Go na le lefelo le lentsi, e bile go na le lefelo le le lekaneng.
ty: Ua riro mai te minivan ei fare nainai roa: te parahi ra vau i nia i te parahiraa horopatete, oia hoi te den. Te mana'o nei au e, teie te piha maitai roa a'e i roto i te fare : e mea rahi te area, e e mea au maitai te parahiraa.
mai: मिनीवैन एक तरहक बहुत छोट घर बनि गेल अछि: हम यात्री सीटपर बैसल छी, जे अड्डा अछि। हमरा लगैत अछि जे ई घरक सबसँ नीक कोठरी अछि: एतय बहुत जगह अछि, आ कुर्सी बहुत आरामदायक अछि।

en: I turn and look out at the highway as I hear a car coming. The white beast and her spotted friend have successfully ambled to the safety of the opposite shoulder, still impassive. Turning back, I realize the minivan is against the fence.
en_results: "title": "The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy", "author": "Douglas Adams"
vi: Tôi quay lại nhìn ra đường cao tốc khi nghe thấy tiếng ô-tô chạy đến. Cô nàng trắng muốt và anh bạn đốm đã thủng thẳng ở vùng an toàn trên vai đường đối diện, vẫn rõ là nhởn nhơ vô tự lự. Quay lại, tôi thấy chiếc minivan đang húc vào hàng rào.
tr: Bir arabanın geldiğini duyunca dönüp anayola bakıyorum. Beyaz canavar ile benekli arkadaşı sahnarak karşı bankete geçip başanlı bir şekilde kendilerini emniyete almışlar, hâlâ umursamazlar. Arkama dönünce minivanın çite dayalı olduğunu fark ediyorum.
es: Oigo un coche, así que me giro y miro hacia la autopista. La bestia blanca y su amiga con manchas han llegado tranquilamente, sanas y salvas, a la otra cuneta, impasibles. Al volver a girarme veo que el monovolumen está contra la valla.
vi_translation: I turned back to look at the highway when I heard the sound of a car approaching. The pure white girl and her spotted friend were leisurely in the safe zone on the opposite shoulder, still clearly carefree and untroubled. Turning back, I saw the minivan crashing into the fence.
tr_translation: When I hear a car coming, I turn and look at the main road. The white monster and its spotted friend trot across to the opposite bank. They have successfully secured themselves, still indifferent. When I turn around, I notice that the minivan is leaning against the fence.
es_translation: I hear a car, so I turn around and look towards the highway. The white beast and its spotted friend have calmly arrived, safe and sound, at the other shoulder, unperturbed. When I turn around again, I see that the minivan is against the fence.
st: Ke ile ka sheba 'me ke sheba tsela e kholo ha ke ntse ke utloa koloi e tla. Sebata se tšoeu le motsoalle oa hae oa mahlo li atlehile ho ts'oana lehetleng le fapaneng, le ntse le se na letho. Ha ke khutlela morao, ke hlokomela hore minivan e khahlanong le terata.

Sebatana se sesweu le tsala ya gagwe e e bofitlha e ne ya atlega ka katlego mo tshireletsong ya legetleng le le farologaneng, e sa ntse e sa tlhole e le teng. Ke a bona, ke a itse gore go na le batswana ba ba neng ba le mo go lone.

en: He pats my uninjured cheek with a greasy hand. “I did it to save myself, not you,” he says. “Believe me when I say that you did not once cross my mind.”
vi: Ben quệt bàn tay lem nhem dầu xe lên bên má lành của tôi. “Tôi làm thế để tự cứu mình chứ cứu gì ông,” nó nói. “Tin tôi đi, trong đầu tôi lúc đó không nghĩ tí tị tèo teo nào đến ông cả.
tr: Yağlı eliyle yaralı olmayan yanağıma vuruyor. “Kendimi kurtarmak için yaptım, seni değil,” diyor. “İnan ki sen aklıma bir kez bile gelmedin.
es: Me da una palmada en la mejilla con su mano grasienta. —Lo he hecho para salvarme a mí mismo, no a ti —contesta—. No he pensado en ti ni un segundo, créeme.
vi_translation: Ben wiped his greasy, oil-stained hand on my uninjured cheek. "I did it to save myself, not you," he said. "Believe me, at that moment, you didn't cross my mind at all."
tr_translation: He hits my uninjured cheek with his greasy hand. “I did it to save myself, not you,” he says. “Believe me, you never crossed my mind even once.”
es_translation: He gives me a slap on the cheek with his greasy hand. —I did it to save myself, not you —he replies—. I haven't thought about you for even a second, believe me.

en: Radar says, “Hey guys, do you remember that time I was double-seat-belted in the wayback and the door flew open and the beer fell out but I survived completely uninjured? How is that even possible?”
en_results: "title": "Is Everyone Hanging Out Without Me?", "author": "Mindy Kaling"
vi: Radar tiếp tục, “Các cậu có nhớ không hồi nớ tớ ở ghế sau ngủ mơ nói mớ cửa xe tự dưng mở chớ bia chảy ào ào qua tớ mà sao tớ khỏe re thế này tớ không nhớ sao mà kì diệu quớ!”
vi_results: "title": "The Diary of a Cricket", "author": "Nguyễn Nhật Ánh"
tr: Radar, “Hey çocuklar, arka tarafta çift emniyet kemeriyle bağlanmış olduğum, kapımn aniden açıldığı ve biranın döküldüğü ama benim kesinlikle yaralanmadan kurtulduğum zamanı hatırlıyor musunuz? Bu nasıl mümkün olabilir ki?” diyor.
es: —Eh, chicos, ¿recordáis aquella vez en que estaba tumbado en la parte de atrás, con los dos cinturones de seguridad puestos, y la puerta se abrió de golpe, todas las cervezas se rompieron, pero sobreviví totalmente ileso? —dice Radar—. ¿Cómo es posible?
vi_translation: Radar continued, "Do you guys remember that time when I was sleeping in the back seat and talking in my sleep, and the car door suddenly opened and beer poured all over me, but I felt completely fine? I don't remember how it happened, it's so miraculous!"
tr_translation: Radar, "Hey kids, do you remember the time I was strapped in the back with a double seatbelt, my door suddenly opened, and the beer spilled but I definitely escaped without injury?" "How could that be possible?" he says.
es_translation: —Hey, guys, do you remember that time when I was lying in the back, with both seat belts on, and the door suddenly opened, all the beers broke, but I survived completely unscathed? —says Radar—. How is that possible?

en: “Bullshit!” I shout, which it mostly is. “You were just playing with us, weren’t you? You just wanted to make sure that even after you left to go have your fun, you were still the axis we spun around.”
en_results: "title": "The Perks of Being a Wallflower", "author": "Stephen Chbosky"
vi: “Nói vớ vẩn gì vậy!” tôi quát, gần như vậy. “Cậu chỉ chơi bọn tớ thôi đúng không? Cậu chỉ muốn đảm bảo rằng dù đã ra đi và có trò vui mới, nhưng cậu sẽ vẫn là cái trục để bọn tớ xoay mòng mòng xung quanh.
tr: “Saçmalama!” diye bağırıyorum çünkü genel olarak saçmalıyor. “Sadece bizimle oynuyordun, değil mi? Eğlenmek için çekip gittikten sonra bile, hâlâ etrafında döndüğümüz eksen olduğundan emin olmak istedin.
es: —¡Gilipolleces! —grito, y en buena medida lo son—. Solo estabas jugando con nosotros, ¿verdad? Solo querías asegurarte de que incluso después de marcharte a divertirte por ahí, todo seguía girando a tu alrededor.
vi_translation: “What nonsense are you talking about!” I shouted, almost like that. “You’re just playing us, right? You just want to make sure that even though you’ve left and have new fun, you will still be the axis around which we revolve.”
tr_translation: “Stop talking nonsense!” I shout because, generally, he is talking nonsense. “You were just playing with us, weren't you? Even after you left to have fun, you wanted to make sure you were still the axis around which we revolved.”
es_translation: —Nonsense! —I shout, and to a large extent, they are—. You were just playing with us, weren't you? You just wanted to make sure that even after you left to have fun elsewhere, everything still revolved around you.

en: She’s screaming back, louder than I thought possible. “You’re not even pissed at me, Q! You’re pissed at this idea of me you keep inside your brain from when we were little!”
vi: Margo hét trả, to hơn tôi nghĩ cô ấy có thể hét được. “Cậu thậm chí còn chẳng thèm nổi cáu với tớ, Q! Cậu chỉ cáu vì những tưởng tượng về tớ mà cậu giữ rịt trong đầu từ hồi bé thôi!”
tr: Karşılık olarak, mümkün olduğunu düşündüğümden daha yüksek sesle çığlık atıyor. “Bana kızgın bile değilsin, Q! Küçüklüğümüzden beri kafanın içinde tuttuğun bana dair fikre kızgınsın!
es: Y ella me grita también, más alto de lo que habría creído posible. —¡Ni siquiera te he decepcionado yo, Q! ¡Te ha decepcionado la idea de mí que te metiste en la cabeza desde que éramos niños!
vi_translation: Margo screamed back, louder than I thought she could scream. “You don't even bother to get mad at me, Q! You're just mad because of the fantasies about me that you've been holding onto since childhood!”
tr_translation: In response, she screams louder than I thought possible. "You're not even mad at me, Q! You're mad at the idea of me that you've kept in your head since we were kids!"
es_translation: And she yells at me too, louder than I would have thought possible. —I haven't even disappointed you, Q! It's the idea of me that you got into your head since we were kids that has disappointed you!

en: As dashed-together escape plans replete with clues go, I thought it was pretty impressive. But mostly I was surprised that she’d wanted me involved in her original plan, too. “Maybe you’ll fill me in,” I said, managing a smile. “I have, you know, been wondering. What was planned and what wasn’t? What meant what? Why the clues went to me, why you left, that kind of thing.”
vi: Khi những kế hoạch chạy trốn được phác vội với nhiều đầu mối ám chỉ sự ra đi, tôi đã nghĩ thế là rất ấn tượng. Nhưng tôi gần như ngạc nhiên rằng trong bản kế hoạch gốc cô ấy cũng muốn tôi tham gia vào. “Có lẽ cậu sẽ kể cho tớ biết chứ,” tôi nói, cố mỉm cười. “Cậu biết đấy, tớ đã thắc mắc nhiều. Điều gì có trong kế hoạch và điều gì không? Cái gì mang ý nghĩa gì? Tại sao các manh mối lại hướng vào tớ, tại sao cậu ra đi, đại khái thế.”
tr: İpuçlanyla dolu, birbirleriyle kesişen kaçış planlan bağlanımda gayet etkileyici olduğunu düşünmüştüm. Ama daha çok, beni asıl planına dâhil etmesine şaşkındım. “Bilmediğim şeylere bir açıklık getirsene,” dedim gülümsemeyi becererek. “Merak ediyordum da... Ne planlıydı, ne değildi? Ne, ne anlama geliyordu? Neden ipuçları bana geldi, neden gittin, böyle şeyler.
es: Como planes de huida precipitados llenos de pistas, me parecieron bastante impresionantes. Pero sobre todo me sorprendía que me hubiera incluido en sus planes desde el principio. —Ya me pondrás al corriente —le dije intentando sonreír—. Bueno, me pregunto muchas cosas. Qué habías planificado y qué no. Qué significaba cada cosa. Por qué las pistas iban dirigidas a mí. Por qué te marchaste…
es_results: "title": "El Príncipe de la Niebla", "author": "Carlos Ruiz Zafón"
vi_translation: When the hastily sketched escape plans with many clues hinting at the departure, I thought it was very impressive. But I was almost surprised that in the original plan she also wanted me to be involved. “Maybe you'll tell me,” I said, trying to smile. “You know, I've been wondering a lot. What is in the plan and what is not? What does everything mean? Why do the clues point to me, why are you leaving, that sort of thing.”
tr_translation: I had thought that the interwoven escape plans filled with clues were quite impressive. But more than that, I was surprised that he included me in his main plan. “Could you shed some light on the things I don't know?” I said, managing to smile. “I was curious... What was planned, what wasn't? What did everything mean? Why did the clues come to me, why did you leave, things like that.”
es_translation: As far as hastily made escape plans full of clues go, they seemed quite impressive to me. But above all, I was surprised that he had included me in his plans from the very beginning. —You'll bring me up to speed —I said, trying to smile—. Well, I wonder about many things. What you had planned and what you hadn't. What each thing meant. Why the clues were directed at me. Why you left…
st: Ha ke ntse ke nahana hore ho na le lintho tse ngata tseo ke neng ke nahana hore ke tsona tse ntle haholo, ke ne ke nahana hore ke ntho e ntle haholo. Leha ho le joalo, ke ile ka makatsoa ke hore le eena o ne a batla hore ke be le karolo ea hae ea pele. "Mohlomong o tla ntjela," ha rialo Mme ka bososela. Ha e le hantle, kea tseba, u ntse u ipotsa. Ke eng e neng e reriloe, 'me e ne e se eona? Ho bolelang? 'Me ke hobane'ng ha u ile a tsamaea ho' na, ke hobane'ng ha u tsamaea, mofuta oo?"
yo: Bí àwọn ètò ìsàlẹ̀ tí ó rẹwà ṣe ń kún fún àwọn ìtọ́sọ́nà tí ó ń lọ, mo rò pé ó wúni lórí gan-an. Ṣùgbọ́n ó yà mí lẹ́nu pé ó ti fẹ́ kí n kópa nínú ètò ìpilẹ̀ṣẹ̀ rẹ̀, náà. "Bóyá wà á kún mi," mo sọ, ṣíṣàkóso ẹ̀rín. "Mo ti, o mọ̀, mo ti ń ṣe ìyàlẹ́nu. Kí ni wọ́n ṣètò àti pé kí ni kò? Kí ni ìtumọ̀? Ìdí tí àwọn ìtọ́sọ́nà náà fi lọ sọ́dọ̀ mi, ìdí tí o fi kúrò, irú nǹkan bẹ́ẹ̀."
tn: Fa go ntse jalo, fa go ne go na le dilo tse di neng di tsamaya ka tsela e e tshwanang, ke ne ke akanya gore go ne go le monate tota. Le fa go ntse jalo, ke ne ke gakgamadiwa ke gore le ene o ne a batla gore ke nne le seabe mo tirong ya gagwe ya ntlhantlha. "O ka nna wa ntshwenya," ha rialo Mme a bososela. Ipotseng, ke a itse gore o a itse gore o teng. Go ne go rulagantswe eng, mme go ne go se kitla go direga eng? Go kaya eng? Ke ka ntlha yang fa go ne go na le dilo tse di molemo tse di neng tsa ntlogela kwa go nna, mme ke ka ntlha yang fa o ne o tlogela dilo tse di ntseng jalo?"
ty: A tere noa ai te tau'araa parau, ua mana'o vau e, e mea faahiahia mau. I te rahiraa râ o te taime, ua maere au i te mea e, ua hinaaro oia ia faaô atoa vau ia'u i roto i ta'na faanahoraa matamua. " Peneia'e e faaî mai oe ia'u ", ta'u ïa parau, ma te ataata. " Ua uiui noa vau, ua ite oe. Eaha tei opuahia e eaha te mea e ore e ti'a ia rave ? Eaha ïa te auraa? No te aha teie mau tapa'o i tae mai ai i ni'a ia'u, no te aha oe i faaru'e ai i te reira huru ohipa ".
mai: जेना-जेना सुरागसँ भरल भागबाक योजना चलैत अछि, हम सोचलहुँ जे ई बहुत प्रभावशाली छल। मुदा अधिकांशतः हम आश्चर्यचकित छलीह जे ओ चाहैत छलीह जे हम अपन मूल योजनामे सेहो शामिल होयब। "भऽ सकैत अछि जे अहां हमरा भरि देब," हम मुस्कुराइत कहलहुँ। "अहां जनैत छी, हम सोचि रहल छी। की योजना छल आ की नहि? की मतलब छल? सुराग हमरा लग किएक गेल, अहां किएक चलि गेलहुं, ओहि तरहक बात।

en: “Um, okay. Okay. For that story, we have to start with a different story.” She gets up and I follow her footsteps as she nimbly avoids the rotting patches of floor. Returning to her office, she digs into the backpack and pulls out the black moleskin notebook. She sits down on the floor, her legs crossed, and pats a patch of wood next to her. I sit. She taps the closed book. “So this,” she says, “this goes back a long way. When I was in, like, fourth grade, I started writing a story in this notebook. It was kind of a detective story.”
en_results: "title": "The Particular Sadness of Lemon Cake", "author": "Aimee Bender"
vi: “Ừ, được. Được rồi. Với câu chuyện đó, chúng ta phải bắt đầu bằng một câu chuyện khác.” Margo đứng dậy, tôi theo sau trong khi Margo bước đi uyển chuyển, tránh những mảng sàn ọp ẹp. Quay trở lại góc làm việc, cô ấy tìm trong ba-lô và lấy ra cuốn sổ bìa da đen. Margo ngồi xuống sàn, bắt chéo chân và vỗ xuống sàn gỗ ngay cạnh cô ấy. Tôi ngồi xuống. Margo mở cuốn sổ ra. “Chuyện này,” cô ấy nói, “vậy là chuyện này bắt đầu từ lâu rồi. Hồi ấy khoảng lớp bốn, tớ bắt đầu viết vào đây. Một kiểu truyện trinh thám.”
tr: “Hımm, tamam. Tamam. Bu hikâye için başka bir hikâyeyle başlamalıyız.” Ayağa kalkıyor, zeminin çürümüş kısımlarından kaçınırken, adımlarım takip ediyorum. Ofisine dönüyor, sırt çantasının içinden siyah defteri bulup çıkarıyor. Bağdaş kurarak yere oturuyor, yanındaki tahta parçasına eliyle hafifçe vuruyor. Oturuyorum. Kapalı deftere hafifçe dokunuyor. “Şimdi bu,” diyor, “uzun zaman öncesine dayamyor. Ben dördüncü sınıfta falanken, bu deftere bir hikâye yazmaya başladım. Bir tür polisiyeydi.
tr_results: "title": "The Particular Sadness of Lemon Cake", "author": "Aimee Bender"
es: Esas cosas. —Hum, vale, vale. Para contarte esa historia, tenemos que empezar por otra. Se levanta y sigo sus pasos, que evitan hábilmente los trozos de suelo podridos. Vuelve a su despacho, mete la mano en la mochila y saca la libreta negra. Se sienta en el suelo, cruza las piernas y da palmaditas al trozo de suelo que está a su lado. Me siento. Apoya la mano en la libreta cerrada. —Esto se remonta a hace mucho tiempo —me dice—. Cuando estaba en cuarto, empecé a escribir un relato en esta libreta. Era una especie de historia de detectives.
vi_translation: “Okay, fine. Alright. With that story, we have to start with another story.” Margo stood up, I followed as Margo walked gracefully, avoiding the creaky floorboards. Returning to the work corner, she searched in her backpack and took out a black leather notebook. Margo sat down on the floor, crossed her legs, and patted the wooden floor right next to her. I sat down. Margo opened the notebook. “This,” she said, “so this started a long time ago. Back around fourth grade, I started writing in here. A kind of detective story.”
tr_translation: “Hmm, okay. Okay. We need to start this story with another story.” He stands up, avoiding the rotten parts of the floor, and I follow his steps. He returns to his office, finds and takes out a black notebook from his backpack. Sitting cross-legged on the floor, he lightly taps the piece of wood next to him with his hand. I sit down. He gently touches the closed notebook. “Now this,” he says, “doesn't go back a long time. When I was in fourth grade, I started writing a story in this notebook. It was a kind of detective story.”
es_translation: Those kinds of things. —Hmm, okay, okay. To tell you that story, we have to start with another one. He gets up and I follow his steps, which skillfully avoid the rotten floorboards. He returns to his office, puts his hand in the backpack, and takes out the black notebook. He sits on the floor, crosses his legs, and pats the piece of floor next to him. I sit down. He rests his hand on the closed notebook. —This goes back a long time —he tells me—. When I was in fourth grade, I started writing a story in this notebook. It was a kind of detective story.
st: "Ho lokile, ho lokile. Ho lokile. Bakeng sa pale ena, re tlameha ho qala ka pale e fapaneng." O ile a tsoha 'me ke latela mehato ea hae, kaha o ne a sa tsebe hore na ke mang ea nang le li-fungus. Ha a khutlela ofising ea hae, o cheka ka har'a mokotla ebe o hula notebook e ntšo ea moleskin. O ile a lula fatše, maoto a hae a tšela, 'me a pata setoana sa patsi haufi le eena. Ke lula fatše. O ile a beha buka e koetsoeng. 'Me a re ho eena, "Ho na le tsela e 'ngoe e tsamaeang ka tsela e telele. Ha ke ne ke le teng, joalo ka kereiti ea bone, ke ile ka qala ho ngola pale bukeng ena ea libuka. "E ne e le mofuta oa litaba tse tsoang ho bafokisi. "
yo: "Um, okay. Ó dáa. Fún ìtàn yẹn, a ní láti bẹ̀rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú ìtàn mìíràn." Ó dìde mo sì tẹ̀lé ìṣísẹ̀ rẹ̀ bí ó ṣe ń yẹra fún àwọn àlẹ̀mọ́ ilẹ̀ tó ń bàjẹ́. Nígbà tí ó padà sí ọ́fíìsì rẹ̀, ó wọ inú àpò ẹ̀yìn ó sì fa ìwé moleskin dúdú náà jáde. Ó jókòó lórí ilẹ̀, ẹsẹ̀ rẹ̀ kọjá, ó sì tẹ igi kan lẹ́gbẹ̀ẹ́ rẹ̀. Mo jókòó. Ó tẹ ìwé tí ó padé náà. Ó sọ pé, "Èyí ti pẹ́. Nígbà tí mo wà ní, bíi, ìpele kẹrin, mo bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí ní kọ ìtàn kan sínú ìwé yìí. Ó jẹ́ irúfẹ́ ìtàn ọ̀tẹlẹ̀múyẹ́."

mai: "उम, ठीक अछि। बेस. ओहि कथाक लेल हमरा एकटा अलग कहानीसँ शुरुआत करय पड़त।" ओ उठैत छथि आ हम हुनक पदचिन्ह पर चलैत छी कियैक तँ ओ फर्शक सड़ैत टुकड़ासँ बचैत छथि। अपन ऑफिस घुरि कऽ ओ बैगमे खोदैत छथि आ कारी मोलस्किनक नोटबुक निकालैत छथि। ओ फर्श पर बैसि जाइत छथि, पैर पार करैत छथि आ बगलमे लकड़ीक एकटा टुकड़ा थपथपाबैत छथि। हम बैठैत छी। ओ बंद किताब के टैप करैत अछि। "तेँ इ," ओ कहैत छथि, "ई बहुत पुरान अछि। जखन हम चारिम कक्षामे छलहुँ, तखन हम एहि नोटबुकमे एकटा कहानी लिखब शुरू केलहुँ। ई एक तरहक जासूसी कहानी छलइ।

Rehefa niverina tany amin'ny biraony izy dia nihady tao anatin'ilay kitapo babena ary nisintona ilay kahie mainty hoditra. Nipetraka teo amin'ny tany izy, niampita ny tongony, ary nanipy tapa-kazo teo akaikiny. Mipetraka aho. Nosintoniny ilay boky mihidy. "Noho izany," hoy izy, "dia miverina lavitra izany. en: I think that if I grab this book from her, I can use it as blackmail. I can use it to get her back to Orlando, and she can get a summer job and live in an apartment till college starts, and at least we’ll have the summer. But I just listen.
en_results: "title": "The Perks of Being a Wallflower", "author": "Stephen Chbosky"
vi: Tôi nghĩ nếu bây giờ giật lấy cuốn sổ từ Margo, tôi có thể dùng nó để đặt điều kiện. Tôi có thể lợi dụng nó để khiến cô ấy phải về Orlando, và Margo sẽ đi làm thêm vào mùa hè, ở trong một căn hộ cho đến khi năm học ở trường đại học bắt đầu, và ít nhất hai đứa sẽ có một mùa hè. Nhưng tôi chỉ lắng nghe.
tr: Eğer bu defteri ondan alırsam, şantaj yapmak için kullanabileceğimi düşünüyorum. Onu Orlando’ya geri götürmek için kullanabilirim, yaz döneminde bir iş bulup üniversite başlayana kadar bir dairede yaşayabilir ve en azından yazı beraber geçiririz. Ama sadece dinliyorum.
tr_results: "title": "The Perks of Being a Wallflower", "author": "Stephen Chbosky"
es: Pienso que si le quitara la libreta, podría hacerle chantaje. Podría utilizarla para que volviera a Orlando, ella podría buscarse un trabajo para el verano y vivir en un apartamento hasta que empezara la universidad, y al menos tendríamos el verano. Pero me limito a escucharla.
es_results: "title": "The Perks of Being a Wallflower", "author": "Stephen Chbosky"
vi_translation: I think if I snatch the notebook from Margo now, I can use it to set conditions. I can leverage it to make her return to Orlando, and Margo will get a summer job, stay in an apartment until the university year starts, and at least the two of us will have a summer. But I just listen.
tr_translation: If I take this notebook from him, I think I can use it for blackmail. I can use it to take him back to Orlando, find a job during the summer, live in an apartment until university starts, and at least spend the summer together. But I'm just listening.
es_translation: I think that if I took her notebook, I could blackmail her. I could use it to make her return to Orlando, she could find a summer job and live in an apartment until college started, and at least we would have the summer. But I just listen to her.

en: “Well,” I say, “I’d rather read it.” She pulls open the book and shows me a page. The writing is indecipherable, not because Margo’s handwriting is bad, but because on top of the horizontal lines of text, writing also goes vertically down the page. “I write crosshatch,” she says. “Very hard for non-Margo readers to decode. So, okay, I’m going to spoil the story for you, but first you have to promise not to get mad.”

vi_translation: "No," I replied, "I'd rather read it myself." Margo opened the book and showed me a page. The handwriting was very hard to read, not because Margo wrote poorly, but because on the horizontal lines, the letters also ran straight down to the bottom of the page. "I write them interwoven like that," Margo explained. "Non-Margo readers would find it hard to decipher. Alright, I'll reveal the plot to you, but you have to promise not to get mad."

en: “I can get behind those burials, I think,” I say. The dirt is clumpy and dry, drilled through with the paths of insects like an abandoned ant farm. We dig our bare hands into the ground over and over again, each fistful of earth accompanied by a little cloud of dust. We dig the hole wide and deep. This grave must be proper. Soon I’m reaching in as deep as my elbows. The sleeve of my shirt gets dusty when I wipe the sweat from my cheek. Margo’s cheeks are reddening. I can smell her, and she smells like that night right before we jumped into the moat at SeaWorld.
vi: “Chắc tớ đuối với những đám tang này quá,” tôi nói. Đất lổn nhổn và khô, dọc ngang đường đi của côn trùng trong lòng đất, trông như một trang trại kiến bị bỏ hoang. Bọn tôi đào bằng tay trần vào đất, mỗi nắm đất đi kèm một đám mây bụi nho nhỏ. Hai đứa đào một cái hố sâu và rộng. Ngôi mộ này thích hợp phải biết. Chẳng mấy chốc tôi đào sâu đến khuỷu tay. Tay áo tôi lem bụi khi tôi quyệt mồ hôi trên má. Hai má cô ấy hồng lên. Tôi ngửi thấy mùi của Margo, cô ấy thơm giống như đêm hôm ấy, ngay trước khi chúng tôi nhảy xuống hào nước ở SeaWorld.

Çıplak ellerimizi tekrar tekrar toprağa sokuyoruz, her avuç dolusu toprağa küçük bir toz bulutu eşlik ediyor. Derin ve geniş bir çukur kazıyoruz. Bu mezar düzgün olmak. es: —Creo que apoyo esos entierros —le digo. La tierra es grumosa y seca, perforada por el paso de insectos como un hormiguero abandonado. Hundimos las manos en el suelo una y otra vez, y cada puñado de tierra arrastra una pequeña nube de polvo. Abrimos un agujero grande y profundo. La tumba debe ser apropiada. No tardo en llegar a los codos. Se me ensucia la manga de la camiseta cuando me seco el sudor de la mejilla. Las mejillas de Margo están cada vez más rojas. Me llega su olor, y huele como aquella noche antes de que saltáramos al foso en el SeaWorld.
vi_translation: “I think I'm overwhelmed with all these funerals,” I said. The ground was rough and dry, crisscrossed with the paths of underground insects, looking like an abandoned ant farm. We dug into the earth with our bare hands, each handful of soil accompanied by a small cloud of dust. The two of us dug a deep and wide hole. This grave is just perfect. Soon, I was digging down to my elbows. My sleeves got dusty as I wiped the sweat off my cheek. Her cheeks turned rosy. I could smell Margo, she smelled just like that night, right before we jumped into the moat at SeaWorld.
tr_translation: “I can't miss these funerals,” I say. The soil is clumpy and dry, like an abandoned ant nest, perforated with paths made by insects. We repeatedly dig our bare hands into the soil, and a small cloud of dust accompanies each handful of earth. We are digging a deep and wide hole. This grave must be neat. Soon, I find myself digging up to my elbows. When I wipe the sweat off my cheek, the sleeve of my t-shirt gets dusty. Margo's cheeks are turning red. I can smell her, and it smells just like that night at SeaWorld, right before we jumped into the moat.

en: I have never really thought of him as a person, either. A guy who played in the dirt like me. A guy who fell in love like me. A guy whose strings were broken, who didn’t feel the root of his leaf of grass connected to the field, a guy who was cracked. Like me. “Yeah,” I say after a while as I return to digging. “He was always just a body to me.”
en_results: "title": "The Perks of Being a Wallflower", "author": "Stephen Chbosky"
vi: Tôi cũng chưa từng nghĩ đến bác ấy như một con người. Một người cũng bày trò nghịch đất như tôi. Một người cũng biết yêu như tôi. Một người có những dây nối đã đứt hết, không cảm thấy gốc rễ nhánh cỏ của mình ăn vào lòng đất, một người đã bị nứt ra. Như tôi. “Ừ,” lúc sau tôi nói và quay lại đào tiếp. “Đối với tớ bác ấy luôn chỉ là một cái xác thôi.”

es: Yo tampoco he pensado nunca en él como persona. Un tipo que jugó en la tierra como yo. Un tipo que se enamoró como yo. Un tipo al que se le rompieron los hilos, que no sintió que las raíces de su hoja de hierba estuvieran conectadas con el campo, un tipo que estaba chiflado. Como yo. —Sí —digo al rato, mientras vuelvo a cavar—. Siempre fue solo un cadáver para mí.
vi_translation: I also never thought of him as a human being. A person who also played with dirt like me. A person who also knew how to love like me. A person whose connections were all severed, who couldn't feel the roots of his grass reaching into the earth, a person who had cracked open. Like me. "Yeah," I said after a while and turned back to continue digging. "To me, he was always just a corpse."
tr_translation: I had never thought of him as a real person either. As a man playing in the dirt like me. As a man who falls in love like me. As a man who had broken strings, who had never felt that his own grass blade root was connected to the meadow, a cracked man. Like me. “Yes," I say after a while, returning to digging. “For me, he was always a corpse. always a corpse.”
es_translation: I have never thought of him as a person either. A guy who played on the earth like me. A guy who fell in love like me. A guy whose threads broke, who didn't feel that the roots of his blade of grass were connected to the field, a guy who was crazy. Like me. —Yes —I say after a while, as I resume digging—. It was always just a corpse to me.

en: “I like the strings. I always have. Because that’s how it feels. But the strings make pain seem more fatal than it is, I think. We’re not as frail as the strings would make us believe. And I like the grass, too. The grass got me to you, helped me to imagine you as an actual person. But we’re not different sprouts from the same plant. I can’t be you. You can’t be me. You can imagine another well—but never quite perfectly, you know?
vi: “Tớ thích những sợi dây nối. Tớ luôn thích. Vì đó là cách để cảm nhận. Nhưng những dây nối khiến nỗi đau có vẻ dễ dẫn đến cái chết hơn thực tế, tớ nghĩ vậy. Ta không mỏng manh dễ đứt như những sợi dây khiến ta tin như vậy. Và tớ cũng thích cỏ. Cỏ đưa tớ đến với cậu, giúp tớ hình dung ra cậu là một con người thật. Nhưng bọn mình không phải là những nhánh khác nhau trên cùng một cây. Tớ không thể là cậu. Cậu không thể là tớ. Ta có thể tưởng tượng rất đúng về người khác–nhưng không bao giờ tương đối hoàn hảo cả, cậu hiểu chứ?
tr: “İpleri seviyorum. Hep sevdim. Çünkü öyle hissediyorum. Ama ipler, acının, olduğundan daha ölümcül görünmesine neden oluyor sanırım, iplerin bizi inandırdığı kadar dayanıksız değiliz. Ve çimeni de seviyorum. Çimen beni sana getirdi, seni gerçek bir insan olarak hayal etmeme yardımcı oldu. Ama biz aynı bitkinin farkh filizleri değiliz. Ben sen olamam. Sen de ben olamazsın. Başka birini iyi bir şekilde hayal edebilirsin... ama asla tamamen kusursuz olmaz, anlıyor musun?
es: —Me gustan los hilos —sigo diciendo—. Siempre me han gustado. Porque así lo siento. Pero creo que los hilos hacen que el dolor parezca más fatal de lo que es. No somos tan frágiles como nos harían creer los hilos. Y también me gusta la hierba. La hierba me ha traído hasta ti, me ha ayudado a imaginarte como una persona real. Pero no somos brotes diferentes de la misma planta. Yo no puedo ser tú. Tú no puedes ser yo. Puedes imaginarte a otro… pero nunca perfectamente, ¿sabes?
es_results: "title": "The Particular Sadness of Lemon Cake", "author": "Aimee Bender"
vi_translation: "I like the connecting threads. I've always liked them. Because they are a way to feel. But the threads make the pain seem more likely to lead to death than it actually does, I think. We are not as fragile as the threads make us believe. And I also like grass. Grass brings me to you, helps me imagine you as a real person. But we are not different branches on the same tree. I cannot be you. You cannot be me. We can imagine others very accurately—but never relatively perfectly, you understand?
tr_translation: “I love ropes. I always have. Because that's how I feel. But I think ropes make pain seem more deadly than it is, we are not as fragile as the ropes make us believe. And I love grass too. Grass brought me to you, helped me imagine you as a real person. But we are not different sprouts of the same plant. I cannot be you. And you cannot be me. You can imagine someone else in a good way... but it will never be completely perfect, do you understand?
es_translation: —I like threads —I continue saying—. I've always liked them. Because that's how I feel. But I think threads make pain seem more fatal than it is. We are not as fragile as threads would have us believe. And I also like grass. The grass has brought me to you, it has helped me imagine you as a real person. But we are not different sprouts from the same plant. I cannot be you. You cannot be me. You can imagine another... but never perfectly, you know?
